lines.text: So few people can boast that they've lost a flying saucer and a man from Mars -all in the same day! Wonder what they'd have done to Columbus if he'd discovered America, and then mislaid it.
An intellectual carrot. The mind boggles.

North Pole, November Third, Ned Scott reporting. One of the world's greatest battles was fought and won today by the human race. Here at the top of the world a handful of American soldiers and civilians met the first invasion from another planet. A man by the name of Noah once saved our world with an ark of wood. Here at the North Pole, a few men performed a similar service with an arc of electricity. The flying saucer which landed here and its pilot have been destroyed, but not without causalities among our own meager forces. I would like to bring to the microphone some of the men responsible for our success... but as Senior Air force officer Captain Hendry is attending to demands over and above the call of duty... Doctor Carrington, the leader of the scientific expedition, is recovering from wounds received in the battle.

[Softly]
Good for you, Scotty.
Everyone of you listening to my voice, tell the world, tell this to everybody wherever they are. Watch the skies. Everywhere. Keep looking. Keep watching the skies.
There are no enemies in science, only phenomena to be studied.
[last lines]
Watch the skies, everywhere! Keep looking. Keep watching the skies!
Think of what it means to the world!
I'm not working for the world. I'm working for the Air Force.

[about the carrot]
Its development was not handicapped by emotional or sexual factors.
You're doing more than breaking army orders. You're robbing science of the greatest secrets that ever come to it.
You'd better go back, Doctor.
Knowledge is more important than life, Captain. We've only one excuse for existing - to think, to find out, to learn.
What can we learn from that thing except a quicker way to die?
It doesn't matter what happens to us. Nothing counts except for our thinking. We thought our way into nature. We split the atom.
Yes, and that sure made the world happy, didn't it?
Knowledge is more important than life.
What if he can read our minds?
He'll be real mad when he gets to me.
[referring to McPherson's gun]
You sure you know how to use that thing?
I saw Gary Cooper in "Sergeant York."
Find anything, Captain?
Not a sign. We poked into every snowbank within miles.
Barnes flushed a polar bear.
Sure did.
Scare you?
Not after I saw it was only a bear.
We owe it to the brain of our species to stand here and die... without destroying a source of wisdom.
[after a quick encounter with the Thing]
Did you get your picture?
No, you were in the way and the door wasn't open long enough.
You want us to open it again?
NO!
No pleasure, no pain... no emotion, no heart. Our superior in every way.
I've given all the orders I want to give for the rest of my life.
If I thought that was true I'd ask you to marry me.
Wait a minute, Scotty. You won't need any boots. When it comes you go back with the others. You don't belong out here.
I didn't belong at Alamein or Bougainville or Okinawa. I was just kibitzing. And I write a very good obit, a obituary to use.
Please doctor, I've got to ask this. It sounds like, well, just as though you're describing some form of super carrot.

Dr. Carrington, you're a man who won the Nobel Prize. You've received every kind of international kudos a scientist can attain. If you were for sale I could get a million bucks for you from any foreign government. I'm not, therefore, gonna stick my neck out and say you're stuffed absolutely clean full of wild blueberry muffins, but I promise my readers are gonna think so.
Say that again!
[She observes cold breath coming out of Scotty's mouth]
Oh Nikki, not you, too!
No, silly, your breath!
Well, I'm sorry, but I've been under a great deal of strain lately!
Oh, you ninny, look!
Here's the sixty-four dollar question - what do you do with a vegetable?
Boil it.
What did you say?
Boil it... bake it... stew it... fry it?
What if we haven't enough voltage?
Just keep swinging at its arms.
[repeated line]
Who wants some coffee?
Close the door!
Do you really drink all those drinks?
Um -hum.
Every one of 'em? You didn't spill one?
Uh -uh.
Holy cats, I thought I was good.

[oft repeated exchange]
I think you're right, sir.
I think you are.
I doubt that it *can* die... as we understand dying.
You're acting like frightened children.
You're right, Doctor... I am frightened.
And don't tell me I'm right.

[after the crew has circled the ice]
We found one! We found a flying saucer!

[This is the 'Japanese Torture' sequence in Nikki's room, with Hendry bound]
You can tie my hands!
Might not be such a bad idea! You suggested it!
I'll bring a rope!
Well Captain, can we start now?
You mind telling me where we're going, Doctor?
Forty-eight miles due east from here.
Your message said an airplane had crashed. Is that what we're looking for?
I don't know, Captain.
I think you'd better explain, Doctor.
Oh, I'm sorry. Miss Nicholson, would you mind reading Captain Hendry my first notes?
Surely.
I was thinking only of the vagueness of my information. I dislike being vague.
Miss Nicholson.
Yes, Doctor?

10 AM the hand became alive. The temperature of the forearm showed a 20-degree rise. Because of this rise in temperature I believe it was able to ingest the canine blood with which it was covered. I believe...
You mean... You mean it lives on blood.

[heard over P.A]
Come on, Mr. Martian and get some nice Scotch blood. One hundred proof. Nothing like it... for babies!
Hey Pat! The heat's off in the mess hall!
No more oil coming in.
Pat, it's off in there, too. Could the tank be empty?
Filled the day before yesterday.
The main line could be plugged. You better run outside and fix it.
And probably run smack into our visitor. He'll be waiting for you to do just that.
We underestimate this guy.
Anybody around here want some coffee?
No, but you can come in.
That's the only reason I brought it. I was hoping you'd ask me.
Dr. Carrington, we just learned you found a dog in there bled white by our visitor. You didn't report it. Why?
I didn't consider it necessary.
But it was necessary to leave two of your friends in there to be killed.
I posted them as a guard. I was in there myself...
Dr. Stern was right. I looked through that door. They're hanging in there upside down like in a slaughterhouse. I wish you'd seen it.
Isn't there something we can do about it?
They're dead now and it's our job to see that nobody else joins them.

[getting ready to go in after The Thing]
Ready, Bob?
No, but go ahead and open it.

to think, to find out, to learn! It doesn't matter what happens to us. Nothing matters except our thinking. We've fought our way into Nature, we've split the atom... We owe it to the brain of our species to stay here and die, without destroying a source of wisdom. Civilization has given us orders!

[Annoyed]
Get him out of here!
